title: How to use the definite article 'the' accurately - Quora

response.answer_text: In general: You use “the” when both you and the person to whom you are speaking (or writing) know which one you are referring to. They might know because you mentioned it in the previous sentence, and now you are referring back to the same one: I met a man last week. The man grew up in the same town as me. The might know because it is universal: Look at the sun. They might know because it is modified to make it definite: I am looking for the jacket (that I left here yesterday). They might know because of shared context: Pass the salt. Close the door. Here comes the professor. They might know because it’s unique by being superlative: the tallest man in my class; the largest country in the world; the first man on the moon. If none of these apply, if it’s new information, if it’s a generalization, then you do not use The. I bought a new car. (I know what I bought, but you do not know yet.) Dogs are more intelligent than cats. (generalization) A pen is more useful than a pencil. (any pen). ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ If it applies to *any, use a or an. If you could say That one, This one, use The. ~~~~~~~~~~~ Then there are specific idiomatic uses: the Himalayas but Mt. Everest. the Pacific Ocean but Lake Baikul the University of Chicago but Merrimack College go to the bank, the movies, the post office, the doctor, in the hospital (American usage), in the dictionary. . a cold, the flu, pneumonia. the measles, the chicken pox, the mumps. but cancer, a headache, a broken arm.

Generally, you use ‘the’ before all nouns that aren’t proper nouns. A proper noun can be a person’s name, official organization or title of a work, or anything of that nature. Here’s an example of ‘the’ in a sentence with regular nouns. “The woman walked the dog down the block” With proper nouns, you’d have a sentence like this: “Bill met Mary at the store.” The can be used with proper nouns in some cases. See the following link: Proper Use of Articles in English Grammar for Writing Papers

As you have rightly said, “the” is a definite article. So it follows from there that you must use it only when you are talking about a definite person, place or thing (noun). Read the examples below. A cow was crossing the road. The cow Ram sold last week died yesterday. This is not the India of my childhood. The Harry I know would never lie.
Use “the” when you are referring to anything specific. Sample sentence: The boy who looked for you yesterday is back. Sample of a non-specific sentence: A boy looked for you yesterday.
Just consider…… Bring me a book ( any book ) indefinite article. Bring me the blue book ( not any book, the blue one ). Definite articles. Books ? I love books (All books ….no article ).
There are websites with helpful information about when to use “the”. Here is one of them: definite article: the
